September 11 in Shady Side,

understanding of the marine

BY MARK TRACHTENBERG

GHCC Opposes GAM
At its first meeting since this summer, the Greater Homewood Community Corporation (GHCC) Board voted Tuesday
night to support the Charles Village Civic Association in opposing
Phi Gamma Delta's relocation to Charles Street.
CVCA chairman Jeffrey Hanes outlined the issues raised
by the fraternity's proposed move and suggested that the GHCC
draft a letter backing the Civic Association. Calling GAM "the
biggest Animal House on the Hopkins campus," Hanes alleged
that the security and peace of mind of the neighborhood residents would be threatened by GAM's presence on the 29th block
of Charles Street. "Those kids will do anything but mug you,"
commented one Board member. "They leave litter on the lawns,
create a lot of noise, keep people awake."
Some Board members wondered whether the group should
take a position without consulting the Tuscany-Canterbury
representative of the GliCC, who was absent at the meeting.
However, since the hearing to determine the zoning status of the
house on Charles Street is scheduled for Oct. 6, the Board decided to act. A motion to draft a letter to send to the Board of
Municipal and Zoning Appeals in opposition to GAM's proposed
move passed 7-4 with three abstentions.
Since no member of the Hopkins Student Council attended
the meeting, the only University representative present was Dea
Kline, head of Community Affairs. Kline objected on procedural
grounds, complaining that since Hanes' presentation was not on
the agenda for the meeting she had had no chance to ascertain the
University's stand on the issue.

four concerts at the first Unitarian Church on Charles Street
between October 18 and April 4. This group of young professional musicians is devoted to performing and building an audience for contemporary (20th century) music. In its repertoire of
recent artists. Hodie will pay particular attention to Baltimore
and Maryland composers.

A radio station based in the freshman dorms should admit its humble origins
and open itself up to increased student
participation. It's true that activity organizations — and the News-Letter is no exception — tend to be cliquish. Each organization has its core group, the people who are
genuinely interested and who put regular
time into the organization's upkeep, and
not surprisingly, these people tend to end
up running the show.
Who's running the shows is the big
question at WJHU right now, but the
answer presents more problems than simply
"a clique." The clique at what is supposedly the Hopkins radio station has a number
of members who arc not Hopkins students,
or even former Hopkins students. Personnel, both on the management and disc
jockey level, include an assortment of
outsiders who range from high school kids
to 35-year-old unemployed professionals.
One undeniable result has been that there
are Hopkins students who haven't gotten
shows. It is not clear that whether this has
happened because of intentional exclusionary tactics on the part of the station, or
because of just plain incompetence, but the
fact is that students who have made repeated demonstration tapes have often not had
their tapes listened to or approved.
The situation seems to be improving
this semester, but the issue has been a
recurring one over the past few years. With
WJHU's self-proclaimed goal of financial
self-sufficiency, coupled with its projected
expansion to a larger broadcasting range.
control of the station's policies may
shortly be beyond most students' reach.
University administrators say that because
the station is not funded through the SAC.
it is not required to hire Hopkins students
exclusively, or even to give them priority.
WJHU's directors argue that they are
aiming at a high level of professionalism,
and are therefore particular about who
they put on the air. They also say that
the non-students are hired in the summer,

when students supposedly aren't around,
and are then retained during the school
year to insure continuity.
The absence of a WJHU constitution
further frees the station from any duty to
hire students.
The issue here is what the true
purpose of a college radio station should
be. First and foremost, it should be a place
where college students can get experience
on the air. Professionalism is a commendable objective, but there's plenty of time in
later life for it to be an overriding concern.
While WJHU, with its FCC license, does
have an obligation to its listeners — an
obligation that will become increasingly
important as the station expands in range —
its primary obligation should always be to
the students at this university. If that
outlook is in danger of changing, perhaps
an FCC license is simply not worth it.
If WJHU is really forced to hire
non-students in the summer — and this
seems questionable, as many students hang
around in the summer, and the station does
little to publicize openings at that time of
year — then at the very least it should
reserve a majority of slots for students

Don't Remake Grades
To the Editor:
It was with some consternation that I read the News-Letter
recommendation of plus-minus
grading. I offer the following
context within which this issue
may be viewed.
Any grading system has
1)
basically two distinct purposes.
First of all, it tells the student
how he is doing. Second, it tells
others how that person has
done. The requirements set by
these criteria are not identical.
If, in the News-Letier's view, it
is desirable that a student 'not
kid himself' about how he is
doing, then the logical conclusion involves a straight percentage style grade, out of 100.
Thus, there would be no reasonable doubt on anyone's part.
However, any grading system
must take into .account our
second factor, and this one is the
most important. Students expect to use their grades to some
concrete purpose: grad school,
etc. In this respect, the Hopkins
student is set against students
from all over the country, and
the fairest system in this case is
quite simply the one which
allows for a fair comparison.
2) Nobody is perfect. Grades
inherently reflect a subjective
evaluation by one person of
another's performance. Further
categorization of grades is inherently more precise on paper. but
does it accurately reflect a
student's grasp of the material?
The whole point of the five
grades is that they correspond to
five different levels of achievement-A=excellent,etc. What the
Academic Council and the NewsLetter seem to have forgotten
in this whole muddle is that
letter grades symbolize these
ideas.as the Hopkins catalogue
indicates. Anyone who has done
excellent work receives an 'A'.
What is our equivalent to an
A-minus, 'sort of excellent?'
The whole point is that grades
where designed to designate
general levels of achievement,
rather than to single out the
minutiae of one's performance.
Further accuracy may not really
be accurate .at all in terms of
evaluating a student's general
performance in a subject area.
At some point, one simply must
accept the idea of arbitrary
levels of performance. and.let's
face it, the differences between
an A and an A-minus in any sort
of subject are much more likely
to reflect the bias of an instructor, or a chance slip on the part
of the student, than to accurately measure general knowledge.
In conclusion, I feel that
grades ought to indicate the
GENERAL quality of a student's work. The more specific
one becomes, the more the
human element intrudes into
this measurement.
David Hurwitz

A radio station based in the freshman dorms should admit its humble origins
and open itself up to increased student
participation. It's true that activity organizations — and the News-Letter is no exception — tend to be cliquish. Each organization has its core group, the people who are
genuinely interested and who put regular
time into the organization's upkeep, and
not surprisingly, these people tend to end
up running the show.
Who's running the shows is the big
question at WJHU right now, but the
answer presents more problems than simply
"a clique." The clique at what is supposedly the Hopkins radio station has a number
of members who arc not Hopkins students,
or even former Hopkins students. Personnel, both on the management and disc
jockey level, include an assortment of
outsiders who range from high school kids
to 35-year-old unemployed professionals.
One undeniable result has been that there
are Hopkins students who haven't gotten
shows. It is not clear that whether this has
happened because of intentional exclusionary tactics on the part of the station, or
because of just plain incompetence, but the
fact is that students who have made repeated demonstration tapes have often not had
their tapes listened to or approved.
The situation seems to be improving
this semester, but the issue has been a
recurring one over the past few years. With
WJHU's self-proclaimed goal of financial
self-sufficiency, coupled with its projected
expansion to a larger broadcasting range.
control of the station's policies may
shortly be beyond most students' reach.
University administrators say that because
the station is not funded through the SAC.
it is not required to hire Hopkins students
exclusively, or even to give them priority.
WJHU's directors argue that they are
aiming at a high level of professionalism,
and are therefore particular about who
they put on the air. They also say that
the non-students are hired in the summer,

when students supposedly aren't around,
and are then retained during the school
year to insure continuity.
The absence of a WJHU constitution
further frees the station from any duty to
hire students.
The issue here is what the true
purpose of a college radio station should
be. First and foremost, it should be a place
where college students can get experience
on the air. Professionalism is a commendable objective, but there's plenty of time in
later life for it to be an overriding concern.
While WJHU, with its FCC license, does
have an obligation to its listeners — an
obligation that will become increasingly
important as the station expands in range —
its primary obligation should always be to
the students at this university. If that
outlook is in danger of changing, perhaps
an FCC license is simply not worth it.
If WJHU is really forced to hire
non-students in the summer — and this
seems questionable, as many students hang
around in the summer, and the station does
little to publicize openings at that time of
year — then at the very least it should
reserve a majority of slots for students
at the start of the new semester. If unemployed professionals are willing to put in a
lot of time for no pay, they'll be willing to
put in a little less at the same salary.
The station should also revive its old
AM station as a training ground for new
people, but this should in no way serve as a
rationale for having a closed door policy on
FM.

Enough people have complained
about WJHU's accessibility to make it clear
that the station is being run by a clique
more exclusive than usual. The University
administration, while it still controls the
station's purse-strings, should establish
some guide-lines for the management of
WJHU that will ensure unhampered student
participation. The situation should be
resolved now, while it still can be.

Don't Remake Grades
To the Editor:
It was with some consternation that I read the News-Letter
recommendation of plus-minus
grading. I offer the following
context within which this issue
may be viewed.
Any grading system has
1)
basically two distinct purposes.
First of all, it tells the student
how he is doing. Second, it tells
others how that person has
done. The requirements set by
these criteria are not identical.
If, in the News-Letier's view, it
is desirable that a student 'not
kid himself' about how he is
doing, then the logical conclusion involves a straight percentage style grade, out of 100.
Thus, there would be no reasonable doubt on anyone's part.
However, any grading system
must take into .account our
second factor, and this one is the
most important. Students expect to use their grades to some
concrete purpose: grad school,
etc. In this respect, the Hopkins
student is set against students
from all over the country, and
the fairest system in this case is
quite simply the one which
allows for a fair comparison.
2) Nobody is perfect. Grades
inherently reflect a subjective
evaluation by one person of
another's performance. Further
categorization of grades is inherently more precise on paper. but
does it accurately reflect a
student's grasp of the material?
The whole point of the five
grades is that they correspond to
five different levels of achievement-A=excellent,etc. What the
Academic Council and the NewsLetter seem to have forgotten
in this whole muddle is that
letter grades symbolize these
ideas.as the Hopkins catalogue
indicates. Anyone who has done
excellent work receives an 'A'.
What is our equivalent to an
A-minus, 'sort of excellent?'
The whole point is that grades
where designed to designate
general levels of achievement,
rather than to single out the
minutiae of one's performance.
Further accuracy may not really
be accurate .at all in terms of
evaluating a student's general
performance in a subject area.
At some point, one simply must
accept the idea of arbitrary
levels of performance. and.let's
face it, the differences between
an A and an A-minus in any sort
of subject are much more likely
to reflect the bias of an instructor, or a chance slip on the part
of the student, than to accurately measure general knowledge.
In conclusion, I feel that
grades ought to indicate the
GENERAL quality of a student's work. The more specific
one becomes, the more the
human element intrudes into
this measurement.
David Hurwitz

Jays Hurler Popko Remembered By Friends
BY JEFF COMEN
AND
TANI LEDER
He was rather awkward looking at first glance. He did
not carry himself with an
athlete's grace, nor did he seem
to want to. He had a unique,
round head of blonde, very
straight hair that often covered
his narrow, slitted eyes. He
sported a rather large belly for
such a great athlete — a belly
enlarged by the numerous bouts
that we all had with the
"brews."
The unusual thing about
this guy, as great a person as he

was, as great a pitcher as he
was, was that he never once got
conceited. The guy was genuinely unselfish, humble, and just
a touch naive. Most importantly, though, he was our true
friend. He touched our lives in a
way that we never thought
anyone could have in such a
short period of time. For the
first time in our young lives we
can unabashedly say that we
loved this guy and that his
memory will live in Our hearts
and minds forever.
On July 13, 1981, Timothy
Popko was killed in a motorcycle accident in Kings Park,
Long Island. He is survived by a

large
and
loving
family.
Timmy's relationship with his
family was indeed a special one.
He took great pride in "perfecting" letters to his parents,
brothers, and sisters.
What
struck us the most about this
relationship was the way he used
to speak of all the members of
his family. He told us of their
experiences and triumphs in
such a way that by the end of
the year we all felt very close to
each one of them. To us, they
seem an extension of Timmy
himself. We just hope that they
realize how much we love and
miss Timmy and that we pray
for their. continued strength in
attempting to deal with the
tragic loss.

Tim Popko was a player of
great potential. His contributions to the 1981 Hopkins
baseball team are numerous. As
a pitcher, he had six of the
team's 20 victories and led the
staff in most of the other major
categories. But statistics were
the furthest thing from Tim's
mind. What was important was
that Hopkins was winning and
winning consistently. You see,
in addition to all of the wins,
saves, and strikeouts he gave to
the 1981 squad, he gave something of far greater value. He
gave the spirit to win. He was a
total team player. He pitched
his heart out for the team's sake,
not his own. He loved to savor
the victories; he took the losses

as hard as anyone. He handled
his second team All-MAC award
as if it were just another routine
strikeout in a clutch situation.
He loved to watch his attitude
and moral spread to the rest
of the team. Yes, the guy ,NPS a
winner as a person and as a ball
player. He was one in a million.
Timmy's image is constantly
with us. Not a day goes by
without the feelings surfacing.
We feel that incredibly painful
longing for a guy who we all
loved so dearly, but lost so
quickly.

sports section of each year's
third issue will be dedicated to
Tim Popko.
